results.name: Triangle T(n, k): Write n in base 2, reverse order of digits, to get the n-th row.
comment: This is the quite common, so-called "bittest" function, see Pari code. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jul 21 2013

For a given number m and a digit position k the corresponding sequence index n can be calculated by n(m, k) = m*(1 + floor(log_2(m))) - 2^(1 + floor(log_2(m))) + k + 1. For example: counted from right to left, the second digit of m = 13 (binary 1101) is '0'. Hence the sequence index is n = n(13, 2) = 39. - _Hieronymus Fischer_, May 05 2007
A070939(n) is the length of n-th row; A000120(n) is the sum of n-th row; A030101(n) is the n-th row seen as binary number; A000035(n) = T(n, 0). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jun 17 2012
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Rows n = 0..1023 of triangle, flattened
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
formula: a(n) = floor(m/2^(k - 1)) mod 2, where m = max(j|A001855(j) < n) and k = n - A001855(m). - _Hieronymus Fischer_, May 05 2007, Sep 10 2007
program: (PARI) A030308(n,k)=bittest(n,k) \\ Assuming that columns are numbered starting with k=0, as suggested by the formula from R. Zumkeller. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jul 21 2013
(Python) for n in range(20): print([int(z) for z in str(bin(n)[2:])[::-1]]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, Mar 31 2017
A030308_row = lambda n: n.bits() if n > 0 else [0]
for n in (0..23): print(A030308_row(n)) # _Peter Luschny_, Nov 28 2017
